baidu.com.name: Baidu, Inc.

flagsData.justification: Baidu operates under Chinese Communist Party oversight and complies with government censorship directives. CEO Robin Li has publicly stated the company prioritizes government relationships. Baidu AI technology is used in Chinese surveillance systems.
flagsData.definition: Company has significant ties to authoritarian regimes, potentially enabling surveillance, censorship, or human rights violations.

flagsData.justification: Baidu actively censors search results to comply with Chinese government requirements. Content related to Tiananmen Square, Tibet, Taiwan independence, and other sensitive topics is filtered. The company employs thousands of content moderators.
flagsData.definition: Company engages in or enables politically-motivated censorship beyond legal requirements.

flagsData.justification: Baidu, Inc. is a Chinese technology company headquartered in Beijing. Founded in 2000, it operates China's dominant search engine with over 70% market share. Subject to Chinese cybersecurity and data laws.
flagsData.definition: Company is majority-owned by Chinese entities, individuals, or the Chinese state, subjecting it to Chinese data laws and potential government influence.

flagsData.justification: Baidu collects extensive user data through its search engine, maps, cloud services, and AI products. Under Chinese law, this data must be stored in China and made available to authorities upon request.

sources.title: NYT - Chinese Tech Companies and Surveillance

flagsData.definition: Company collects extensive personal data beyond what is necessary for service provision, often for advertising or sale to third parties.

baidu.com.notes: China's dominant search engine. Subject to Chinese censorship requirements.

checkpoint.com.name: Check Point Software Technologies Ltd.

flagsData.justification: Check Point Software Technologies Ltd. is an Israeli multinational cybersecurity company headquartered in Tel Aviv, Israel. Founded in 1993 by Gil Shwed, Marius Nacht, and Shlomo Kramer in Ramat Gan, Israel. Gil Shwed, who served in IDF Unit 8200 (Israeli Intelligence Corps), remains CEO. The company is a major Israeli tech employer and defense contractor.
flagsData.definition: Company has significant ownership, operational, or financial ties to Israeli entities, military, or government.

checkpoint.com.notes: Major Israeli cybersecurity company. Founder Gil Shwed served in IDF Unit 8200.

elbitsystems.com.name: Elbit Systems Ltd.

flagsData.justification: Elbit Systems Ltd. is Israel's largest publicly traded defense company, headquartered in Haifa, Israel. The company is a major supplier to the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and develops military technology including drones, surveillance systems, and weapons systems used in Israeli military operations.
flagsData.definition: Company has significant ownership, operational, or financial ties to Israeli entities, military, or government.

flagsData.justification: Elbit Systems is a primary contractor for the Israel Defense Forces and exports military equipment to over 50 countries. The company provides surveillance systems for border walls, military drones, and defense electronics. It has significant US military contracts through its American subsidiary.
flagsData.definition: Company provides significant services or technology to military organizations.

flagsData.justification: Elbit Systems develops and sells surveillance technology including border monitoring systems, reconnaissance drones, and intelligence gathering equipment. The company's systems are used for surveillance along the Israeli separation barrier and have been exported to border agencies worldwide including US Customs and Border Protection.

sources.title: The Intercept - Elbit Border Technology Investigation

flagsData.definition: Company develops or deploys surveillance technology, including facial recognition, location tracking, or mass monitoring systems.

flagsData.justification: Elbit Systems manufactures a wide range of weapons and military systems including Hermes drones (used in military operations), artillery systems, mortar systems, small arms, and guided munitions. The company is ranked among SIPRI's top 100 arms-producing companies globally.
flagsData.definition: Company manufactures weapons, ammunition, or weapons systems.

elbitsystems.com.notes: Major Israeli defense contractor. Manufactures drones, surveillance systems, and weapons.

nsogroup.com.name: NSO Group Technologies

flagsData.justification: NSO Group is an Israeli technology company headquartered in Herzliya, Israel. Founded by former members of Unit 8200 (Israeli Intelligence Corps). The company's Pegasus spyware has been sold to governments worldwide and has been linked to surveillance of journalists, activists, and political figures.

sources.title: Commerce Adds NSO Group to Entity List

flagsData.definition: Company has significant ownership, operational, or financial ties to Israeli entities, military, or government.

flagsData.justification: NSO Group develops and sells Pegasus spyware, which can be covertly installed on mobile phones to access messages, emails, calls, camera, and microphone. The Pegasus Project investigation by 17 media organizations documented its use against journalists, human rights activists, and political opposition figures across multiple countries.
flagsData.definition: Company develops or deploys surveillance technology, including facial recognition, location tracking, or mass monitoring systems.

nsogroup.com.notes: Developer of Pegasus spyware. Subject to US sanctions and multiple lawsuits.

tencent.com.name: Tencent Holdings Ltd.

flagsData.justification: Tencent operates under Chinese Communist Party oversight with a Party committee embedded in the company. WeChat is used as a tool of state surveillance and censorship. The company actively assists government content moderation and has been cited for sharing user data with Chinese authorities.
flagsData.definition: Company has significant ties to authoritarian regimes, potentially enabling surveillance, censorship, or human rights violations.

flagsData.justification: Tencent's WeChat platform actively censors content for users in China, including political content, news, and images. Citizen Lab research has documented extensive keyword filtering and image censorship even for users outside China communicating with users inside.

sources.title: Citizen Lab - WeChat Surveillance and Censorship

flagsData.definition: Company engages in or enables politically-motivated censorship beyond legal requirements.

flagsData.justification: Tencent Holdings Ltd. is a Chinese multinational conglomerate headquartered in Shenzhen. One of the world's largest tech companies by market cap. Owns WeChat (1.2B+ users), QQ, and major stakes in global gaming companies including Riot Games, Epic Games, and Activision Blizzard.

sources.title: Hong Kong Stock Exchange - Tencent Filings

flagsData.definition: Company is majority-owned by Chinese entities, individuals, or the Chinese state, subjecting it to Chinese data laws and potential government influence.

flagsData.justification: Tencent collects vast amounts of user data through WeChat, QQ, and its gaming platforms. WeChat integrates payments, social media, and services, creating comprehensive user profiles. Data is subject to Chinese government access under national security laws.
flagsData.definition: Company collects extensive personal data beyond what is necessary for service provision, often for advertising or sale to third parties.

tencent.com.notes: Chinese tech conglomerate. Owns WeChat, QQ, and major stakes in gaming companies worldwide including Riot Games, Epic Games.

flagsData.definition: Company has significant ties to authoritarian regimes, potentially enabling surveillance, censorship, or human rights violations.

sources.title: Human Rights Watch - Russia Internet Surveillance

flagsData.definition: Company collects extensive personal data beyond what is necessary for service provision, often for advertising or sale to third parties.

flagsData.definition: Company has significant ownership, operational, or financial ties to Russian entities, individuals, or the Russian state.

vk.com.notes: Russia's largest social network. Now controlled by Kremlin-linked entities after founder Pavel Durov left.

weibo.com.name: Weibo Corporation

flagsData.justification: Weibo operates under direct Chinese government oversight and actively cooperates with state censorship and surveillance. The platform is used by Chinese authorities to monitor public opinion and identify dissent. Users have been detained based on Weibo posts.

sources.title: Amnesty International - Chinese Social Media Censorship

flagsData.definition: Company has significant ties to authoritarian regimes, potentially enabling surveillance, censorship, or human rights violations.

flagsData.justification: Weibo operates one of the most heavily censored social media platforms in the world. The company employs thousands of content moderators and uses AI to detect and remove politically sensitive content. Topics including Tiananmen, Tibet, Xinjiang, and criticism of CCP leadership are systematically censored.

sources.title: Citizen Lab - Chinese Social Media Censorship Research

flagsData.definition: Company engages in or enables politically-motivated censorship beyond legal requirements.

flagsData.justification: Weibo Corporation is a Chinese microblogging platform headquartered in Beijing. Often called 'Chinese Twitter' with over 500 million users. Major shareholders include Alibaba Group (30%) and New Wave Holdings. Subject to Chinese internet regulations.
flagsData.definition: Company is majority-owned by Chinese entities, individuals, or the Chinese state, subjecting it to Chinese data laws and potential government influence.

weibo.com.notes: Chinese microblogging platform, often called 'Chinese Twitter'. Subject to heavy censorship.
